Are you guys aware of the interesting implications of the spaced armor on French cruisers? For instance, HE shells do 0 damage penetrations as they only penetrate the outside layer of armor (even very large caliber HE). And some AP will detonate between the plates doing zero damage (Royal Navy AP specifically).
Details can be found in this thread.
https://www.reddit.com/r/WorldOfWarships/comments/6669wo/unusual_effects_of_spaced_armour_in_the_french/

The execution of the gameplay in parallel with the story is what's so good. The gameplay has narrative to it and I don't just mean that story elements are told through it. I mean that when Joel stealth kills and beats in the heads of 10 guys in a room, that's canon. And stress of that, the frustration of it, the brutality that is demonstrated exists in prefect cohesion with the characters and the story. The gameplay is hard, it wears you down, it's not necessarily fun, and it's perfect for The Last of Us.

The context of the gameplay was to drive the narrative. Comparing it to other games is tricky, because the last of us has gameplay that exists in prefect cohesion with the story. The gameplay is not separate from the narrative, it is canon with it. It is stressful, frustrating, resourceful, and mostly grounded. It's prefect for what it accomplishes

WRITING.TITLE: A little luck, a little skill.

WRITING.TEXT: You should take every reaction of this subreddit with a grain of salt.
Zao, Hindenburg, and Moskva can bounce Yamato AP off the deck. Doesn't overmatch.

There's several circumstances that differentiate the two. You may go undetected vs a Yamato. Torps don't care if you're spotted or who the intended target was. Assuming you're not sitting still, you can also dodge the shells as you can see them coming as they're fired. Angling works vs shells. Des Moines has a particular weakness with it's poor deck, but most cruisers can mitigate Yamato fire. Angling vs torps does nothing. In fact you lose out on torp belt protection (not like it helped much but still).
Does it *feel* good?
Cruisers don't die in one or two Yamato hits. Hyperbole doesn't help discussion.

Granted, a lot has changed since then and I don't really expect Shimas to go back the their prior dominance. More ships run as counters to DDs and Shimakazes will still be missing their super long range torps
-subject2159 from the post you didn't read.
And I stated as much in my post. The majority of what I said is unrelated to what you're pointing out.

I understand your point but I still think it's a little different. A good cruiser player can avoid taking huge damage from a BB very well. And while a good cruiser player can avoid torps, there's still a little less counter play to it, especially considering walls of 15 torps. Sometimes it's very hard or impossible avoid all of them and when they do half or more of your HP, it's very devastating.
DDs are the biggest sufferers though imo. Cruisers have hydro a lot of the time to see torps but DDs act mostly reactionary to them. So a zone being flooded with 15 torps that pop up really close to you, oops you misjudged the turn, oops your rudder was the wrong way when they were spotted, oops those torps luckily were packed in too tightly together to dodge. Insta kill. I just don't think having insta gib mechanics with such a high variability of outcome and response is very engaging. Which goes back to the suggestion of lowering the alpha to begin with, but I don't see WG considering that for some reason.
Ah well let's buff the speed too then.
My opinion is just to buff the detection and nerf the alpha damage. The torps are still the fastest torps in the game, so hitting more consistently but for less burst seems reasonable.
More accurate and easily accessible information is always a good thing.

WRITING.TITLE: Regarding Shimakaze Torps
WRITING.TEXT:
I remember when seeing 4 Shimakazes per team was not out of the ordinary. You guys complain about the passive meta now, but perhaps you look at the past with rose tinted glasses because I remember it being much worse. Granted, a lot has changed since then and I don't really expect Shimas to go back the their prior dominance. More ships run as counters to DDs and Shimakazes will still be missing their super long range torps, but there's an element that is often overlooked when dealing with ways to buff their current underperforming torps.
The individual damage of them. There are arguments to be made about total DPS and how other DDs fire torps more frequently at less damage, but that's only part of the way to look at them. What is important to consider is this higher alpha makes them particularly more deadly against cruisers and DDs when these torps can one or two shot them. People always meme about BBabies crying about torps but I assume it's the DDs and CAs that will be most affected by any spotting range buffs. Any slow moving BBs might take one extra torp to little effect because of a detection buff, but a cruiser taking one extra or a DD being hit at all is a big deal. I don't think WG wants these dramatic consequences.
So, while Shimas are currently underperforming, it's a careful topic to consider as their torps are dangerously close to meta defining. More dangerous Shima torps mean more dangerous and game ending consequences of a single mistake or a single case of bad luck from random torps spreads. And its not BBs that will suffee the most, imo. Be careful what you ask for.
You're all products of confirmation bias.
I am a dead BB.
True, but even making a lower caliber shell do the same damage as a higher caliber would be the first time that's happened (I think). And for what Flamu was calling for would do way more damage.
They would probably not want to give 240mm guns much more alpha than Scharn 280s though.
A high alpha cruiser sounds awesome.
Dodging torps and maneuvering in tight spaces are severely limited. Often I was confident enough with Khab to contest tight points like C cap on Hotspot. Not anymore.

In my experience of not only playing different competitive games, but also following them to an extent, the successful games balance around the top players and the competitive scene.
As far as power creep, there are certainly cases of it and I hope the duca duca doesn't go through as is, but as far as main ship lines, I think have been very balanced. German DDs are a good spot, Grrman BBs are a great example of balance, RN cruisers are weird but situational, French cruisers are probably a little weak but still interesting (which is okay).
All they need to do is remove Belfast from the game and we're in a good spot.

Mosvka is the better BB.
Joking aside, both are great. They offer different things so its hard to call one better.
Mosvka is a bit more static in it's play with poor options for disengaging but very strong when played to it's strengths.
Zao is much more versatile and can freely move around the map in an active way. The stealth fire removal didn't hurt it too much.
Personally I find Mosvka more fun to play because oh how well you can bully people with your insane deck armor and Russian bias guns. Zao is a bit easier and while it does have more freedom for map positioning, it's a bit easier to play and less interesting imo.
Many opinions reflected flamu's from other testers. His opinions were just the most publicized.
Yeah big weakness still.
CVs aren't dead at T7 and below.
But my Russian bias :(
For sure.
Would probably be okay to give every cruiser enough deck armor to not get overmatched by BBs of it's tier.
Even so, you should keep it in mind as a longer term goal. Once you get a 19 point captain it will begin to help out every other captain you have. It's great.
Get a 19 point captain on a T10, play that ship a lot (T10s generate more xp), use it's elite commander xp to level other stuff.

Give Henri more deck armor and give the whole line more krupp and 3 kts more speed.
Fixed and not op.

Very well said. I like your point about situations where the poor torpedo detection plays little to no role. A lot of people use that detection as their main argument against the ship's effectiveness.

Make them faster (the ships), give the shells some more krupp. The line still wouldn't be top tier, but they'd be good enough to be relevant.

I think people forgot there exists a turret rotation module. It's certainly still slow, but certainly very playable.
You fire 15 shell salvos. Gotta be careful how you buff that.

German DDs have proved to be reliable BB escorts in NA competitive. They use their hydro to detect torps from way far out, are good at spamming torps towards enemy lanes and their smoke is long enough to be useful until a benson can come back for the big smoke.
Detection mechanics could still use some work as you say, but I have seen plenty of people criticize the lack of stealth firing directly.

WRITING.TITLE: Are things as bad as people want them to be?
WRITING.TEXT:
Alright alright. I don't intend to say this game is above criticism or that the devs are infallible as they certainly aren't, but holy shit this echo chamber can be a bit exhausting. I won't say that I know everything but I have been playing this game for a long time now and have a decent enough understanding of game mechanics that I feel my opinion should carry some weight to them and not be immediately discredited behind the echo chamber. And some of these opinions being contrary to the general opinion I think makes them worth hearing.
I'd like to list a few heated topics and give my opinions on each. Some I agree with the populace, some I come at with a different point of view.
* Ranked was complete shit and an obvious cash grab on premiums. Every ranked season will obviously push premium sales, but T7 having only premiums with radar and enough smoke going around to make Snoop Dogg cough was painful and I hope it doesn't happen again.
* German DDs being "shit". Are they shit? Maybe they're not the best, but they're certainly better now with the stealth fire change. The T8 German DD has made its way successfully into competitive play in a lot of comps but I'd also like to make a point of power creep. WG went to odd measures to make the RN cruisers relevant and the sense of power creep can be felt everywhere. Not every line has to be the best new ships, they can be kinda meh and still be relevant. Otherwise you get continous power creep.
* Russian bias? Maybe? I mean they are generally strong ships, but so are other lines. Russian ships have a pretty unique playstyle that I think adds to the game balance in a positive way. They separate themselves from the role of other ships without relying on consumable power creep.
* Stealth fire change. Look guys, I remember a time when people were asking for stealth fire to be removed. I know that things change and with radar and hydro it's more scary now for DDs but even still, stealth firing was a hugely situational tactic for the majority of DDs. If you were relying on it I question whether you were playing correctly and the couple ships the change did affect greatly like akizuki, it was needed. Stealth firing akizuki lacks counter play and it's not fun.
* New French ships, stop freaking out, just politely voice concerns and move on.
* ~~Russian T8 BB premium. I don't like it having radar but will 305s will be that good? I imagine they will do fuck all agaisnt a NC and even a lot of cruisers should be able to handle them. It's a Scharnhorst without turtleback sooooo not sure how good it is minus the radar.~~
I've been duped.
tl:dr don't hate me
edit - formatting.
Erik is fucking hilarious. Dude trips me up every time.
Right on time for T8 ranked season. If the bow can be over matched I'll forgive it.
It's not great but it's long enough to be useful.
To be fair heal on Khab isn't inherently OP. No smoke is a pretty big tradeoff for both yourself and teammates. I play with heal just because it's full adrenaline fun.
Thanks bud
This isn't really about the Black vs CA/BB. It's about Black vs other DD being instant win.

I played Chivalry for 1600 hours (mostly conpetitively) and enjoyed my time despite the game's huge mechanical flaws. At a fundamental level, Chivalry offers an insane amount of depth with its swing manipulation. It makes an interesting mind game and reactionary game when you not only have to read the direction of your opponents moves, but also the speed and timing of it (since blocking is a timing based reaction). However, while dragging was an intended mechanic, this depth does bring out exploits that might not necessarily be *as* broken as people think, but certainly take a lot of mechanical understanding and experience to deal with and even for an experienced player, still get tiring to deal with. Players with an over reliance on reverse attacks took away a lot of depth and it was just a game about your ability to react quickly, ping be damned.
Mordhau looks fucking brilliant. Not only have they fixed the reverse attack issue, they also added more depth in the ability to deal with your opponents attacks. In Chivalry, you can parry and that's about it. Some fast weapons can interrupt an opponents moves, but you mostly can just parry. And with feints being so incredibly challenging to read, the person on the offensive has a huge advantage. Mordhau gives more defensive tools to take back the initiative and limits the effectiveness of feints with the counter attack system. It's no longer safe to spam feints hoping your opponent bites, as they can simply queue up their own attack as a counter to any potential swing, feint or not.
tldr looks alright tbh
